stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on Course 15, dedicating most of the stream to debugging a persistent, emulator-specific crash related to a 'styrofoam' visual effect. This led to a design discussion with Biobak and the decision to replace the effect. Kaze also implemented and tuned tilting platforms and briefly showed off a highly-optimized port of Isle Delfino running on N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: A major development challenge is a persistent crash in the Project64 emulator that does not occur on real N64 hardware, making it extremely difficult to debug. The issue is suspected to be a memory corruption bug related to a normal mapping effect.
development_findings.quote: The worst problem is that on real n64 it legit just works.

development_findings.summary: Kaze discovered that changing a function from 'inline' to a standard function call fixed a crash, leading him to believe the root cause is a bug within the Project64 emulator itself rather than his own code.
development_findings.quote: How does changing the function from an inline to not an inline make it work? This garbage emulator man I swear.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has made significant performance optimizations to the game engine, claiming it's up to 7-10 times faster than vanilla SM64. He demonstrated this by showing a port of Super Mario Sunshine's Isle Delfino running at a stable 30 FPS on N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: I just ported this to my current engine... Look at that. Easy 30 fps on N64.

development_findings.summary: The team decided to replace a technically problematic and aesthetically unappealing 'styrofoam' snow effect. The new plan is to use a 'stapled paper on cardboard' theme, and potentially add a pop-able bubble wrap sheet as a gameplay mechanic for a coin.
development_findings.quote: We can't let you just put a bubble wrap there... yeah okay but we need a different solution for the styrofoam then.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively working on Course 15, implementing and tuning platforming elements like tilting bridges and planning the layout for a secret 'hell' area accessed via a zipper.
The game is being developed to fit on a 64 MB ROM, the largest standard size for the N64.
development_findings.quote: The final game will take up pretty much exactly 64 megabytes.

development_findings.summary: The game features a widescreen toggle that increases the horizontal field of view, which Kaze prefers over stretching a 4:3 image, even if it means cutting off a few vertical pixels.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views making YouTube videos as a necessary chore to financially support his true passion, which is game development. He creates content for the viewers to enable his hobby, not because he enjoys the process of video creation itself.
context_findings.quote: I just want to make games, man.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has considered a potential commercial PC release on Steam, and is aware that this would require transforming the project into an original IP by replacing all Nintendo assets to avoid legal issues.
context_findings.quote: If I were to release this game on Steam, obviously I would have to remove all the Mario assets though.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokingly frames the game as a 'quadruple A' title, reflecting his ambition to push the N64's technical and design boundaries far beyond typical ROM hacks.
context_findings.quote: I'm going to say this is the first quadruple A N64 game ever. That's going to be the marketing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's development philosophy prioritizes compatibility and performance on original N64 hardware above all else. He considers emulator-specific bugs and crashes to be the fault of the emulator, not his code.
context_findings.quote: The game boots on N64. And if it boots on N64, then everything's fine, right? And anything after that, the emulator just falls.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses significant frustration with the instability of emulators, particularly Project64, which suffers from random crashes and performance degradation that complicates the debugging process.
Kaze confirms that the game development and YouTube content creation are a hobby, as he has a full-time job as a programmer.
context_findings.quote: My main job is not this my main job is programming for a company.

biobak.summary: Biobak's opinion was sought by Kaze regarding the problematic 'styrofoam' visual effect. His apparent agreement that it wasn't working led to the decision to replace it.
biobak.quote: Biobak do we even want the normal map styrofoam do we think it looks good i don't think it does

biobak.summary: Biobak proposed a new visual concept for the level's background void, involving layered shades of blue. Kaze immediately approved of the idea and planned to implement it.
biobak.quote: I think I like that idea by a bike that looks very good.

zeina.summary: Zeina has friends with technical skills who assisted Kaze by installing the N64 Digital HDMI mod on his console.
zeina.quote: I wasn't the one that installed it. One of Zeina's friends installed it.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions playing games (like Twilight Princess) with Zeina, indicating a shared hobby.
zeina.quote: I've recently been playing Twilight Princess with my wife.

key_stories.title: The Emulator Ghost Crash
key_stories.summary: Kaze hunted down a mysterious emulator-specific crash that didn't occur on real hardware. After a long and frustrating process of elimination, he found a bizarre workaround, ultimately blaming the 'garbage emulator' for the issue.
key_stories.challenge: A persistent and seemingly random crash was plaguing Course 15 in the Project64 emulator, but the game worked perfectly on real N64 hardware, making the bug incredibly difficult to diagnose.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream trying to isolate the crash. He checked memory allocation, analyzed assembly code, tested on different emulators, and suspected memory corruption from a visual effect. The final fix was discovered through trial and error.
key_stories.outcome: After extensive debugging, Kaze found a workaround by changing a specific function from 'inline' to a regular function. He concluded the issue was an obscure bug within Project64 itself, highlighting the frustrations of developing for imperfect emulators.
key_stories.key_quote: How does changing the function from an inline to not an inline make it work? This garbage emulator man I swear.

key_stories.title: Replacing the Styrofoam
key_stories.summary: A complex visual effect for snow was causing crashes and didn't look good. Kaze consulted with artist Biobak on stream, and they collaboratively decided to scrap the feature in favor of a simpler, more creative 'stapled paper' solution.
key_stories.challenge: The 'styrofoam' snow effect in Course 15, which used normal mapping, was not only aesthetically unconvincing but was also the prime suspect for a major memory corruption crash.
key_stories.process: While struggling to fix the crash, Kaze paused to question the effect's artistic merit. He consulted Biobak on stream, who seemed to agree it wasn't worth the trouble. This led to a collaborative decision to pivot to a new 'crafts' based idea.
key_stories.outcome: The team decided to scrap the styrofoam effect entirely. They replaced it with a more thematically appropriate and technically simpler concept of white paper stapled to cardboard, resolving both the visual and technical problems.
key_stories.key_quote: Biobak do we even want the normal map styrofoam do we think it looks good i don't think it does

key_stories.title: The Isle Delfino Demonstration
key_stories.summary: In a moment of pride, Kaze demonstrated the power of his custom engine by showing Super Mario Sunshine's Isle Delfino ported and running at a smooth 30 FPS on an actual N64. This served as a testament to the years of optimization work he has put into the project.
key_stories.challenge: Demonstrating the true power and efficiency of the custom game engine built for the project.
key_stories.process: During the stream, Kaze took a detour to open a separate project file. He loaded a 12,000-triangle model of Isle Delfino and ran it on his N64, explaining that his engine optimizations made this possible.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully showed that the heavily optimized engine could run a complex level from a GameCube game (Isle Delfino) at a stable 30 FPS on N64 hardware, a major technical feat that highlights the project's ambition.
key_stories.key_quote: I just ported this to my current engine, just because I wanted to see how well it runs. Look at that. Easy 30 fps on N64.

open_questions.context: Kaze is adamant that if the game works on a real N64, emulator issues are not his fault. However, he acknowledges a large portion of his audience will use emulators like Parallel, which currently has issues with the game.
